titleInfo.title: Designing Supportive Spaces for Mothers with Children in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit

name.namePart: Department of Interior Architecture and Design

mods:mods.abstract: The sterile Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) environment and critical condition of a hospitalized infant can lead to heightened maternal stress, perinatal generalized anxiety disorder, postpartum depression, and post-traumatic stress disorder (APA, 2020). These states result in damage to the mother and child, as parent-infant attachment and postnatal bonding are delayed. Published recommendations for NICU planning guidelines to support maternal wellness and infant development concurrently is limited. Supportive Design Theory proposes that stress may be alleviated within healthcare settings by providing users with a perceived sense of control, social support opportunities, and positive distraction (Ulrich, 1997). This research study utilized Supportive Design Theory to analyze personal recollections from mothers about experiences within the NICU. Findings reported dominant emerging themes for the three Supportive Design Theory variables. Behaviors that described the lack of or desire for a perceived sense of control were associated with the capability to participate in care times, a monotonous routine, visual awareness of the infant, furnishings accessibility, wayfinding cues, and security. Conduct associated with the desire for or lack of social support opportunities arose as feelings of loneliness, comfort from clinical staff, and bonding with fellow NICU parents. Behaviors illustrating the lack of or desire for positive distraction connected with mental escapes from the NICU environment, such as playing, looking out patient room windows, and watching television. This research study determined how mothers perceive their environments through the lens of Supportive Design Theory. Thus, identifying NICU planning and design strategies to promote maternal mental health and wellness during the perinatal period. This project's design program and solution establishes a standard for the design of a supportive NICU environment which encourages infant growth, healing, and development while simultaneously fostering maternal mental health and wellbeing, thereby promoting infant-parent bonding and attachment in the critical first moments of life.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Interior Architecture and Design in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Fine Arts.
Content Analysis, Healthcare Design, Maternal Mental Health, Maternal Wellbeing, Neonatal Intensive Care Unit, Supportive Design Theory
Marlo Ransdell, Professor Directing Thesis; Jim Dawkins, Committee Member; Stephanie Sickler, Committee Member.
